awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Distributed Control, Optimization and State Estimation of Networked Microgrids with Enhanced Stability
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on advanced control technology development based on new techniques for analysis and enhancement of stability characteristics of networked microgrids, which is a complex system integrated with various distributed energy resource (DER) units. University of Denver has assembled an excellent team for the collaborative GOALI project with our industry partners ENCORP and National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL). The major novelties of the project are: to research the distributed, optimal control strategies and the stability characteristics of microgrids; to explore new control technologies to enhance stability of microgrids; and to pursue technology validation and commercialization with our industry partners. This project is unique because the proposed control methods can optimize generation resources with enhanced stability in a distributed manner. Another unique aspect of this project is the combination of computer simulation and real-time implementation/physical testing for the proposed methods.

Findings from this research can be applied to technologies and demonstrations that shape the future of the electricity grid. The development of networked microgrids along with the proposed control, optimization and analysis methodologies will not only facilitate the increased penetration of distributed renewable energy resources but also enhance the reliable operation of low- or medium- voltage distribution networks.

The proposed research offers a unique research setting unobtainable from pure academic institution. Graduate students and undergraduate students including those from underrepresented groups will benefit greatly from the educational outcome of our proposed research and development work. The principal investigators and senior personnel of this project will pursue a holistic range of activities to promote microgrid and smart grid technologies for research-integrated education and outreach.

Successful penetration of our technology into the energy market will have major societal and commercial impact and contribute in transforming our energy infrastructure to become resilient. Our microgrid control technology will improve security, efficiency, and sustainability of our power and energy infrastructure.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The major research efforts are focused on developing distributed control, state estimation, and optimization technology with new techniques for analysis and enhancement of the stability of networked microgrids, considering the complex interactions among microgrids integrated with various distributed energy resource (DER) units.

During the project period, we mainly did research in the following topics: (1) We proposed the small-signal model and stability-oriented consensus control scheme for inverter-based microgrid systems. The objective function is formulated based on the small-signal stability index and consensus index of microgrid system. (2) We developed a comprehensive microgrids expansion model with a focus on the optimal sizing of battery energy storage (BES) to ensure reliable, resilient, and cost-effective operation of microgrids. (3) We developed a new Optimal power flow (OPF) technique for microgrid power systems to achieve optimal operation while satisfying multiple constraints. We introduced a totally Distributed DC Optimal Power Flow (DDCOPF) method for future power systems which have more and more distributed generators. The new method is completely distributed without need for any centralized facility. (4) We developed a novel simulation approach to evaluate new ancillary service controls in the context of large-scale wind power integration with realistic wind conditions in the field. The developed controller model is rapidly prototyped for the real-time simulation with the hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) scheme. (5) We developed noiseless consensus based economic dispatch algorithm in conjunction with STATCOM controller for reactive power compensation in islanded microgrids and in grid-connected microgrids to enhance voltage and power stability. (6) We developed a fully distributed power system state estimation with novel information propagation algorithm for future power systems which have more and more distributed generators. (7) In order to address the problems associated with deteriorating grid frequency profile and potential power system instability with the increasing integration of renewable energy, we proposed a new inertial control algorithm using Virtual Synchronous Generator (VSG) for wind turbine generator (WTG). (8) We developed a data-driven optimal control strategy for virtual synchronous generator (VSG) without needing expert knowledge and system model. (9) We investigated the problem of distributed cooperative energy management of multiple energy bodies with the consideration of both the optimal energy generation / consumption of each participant within single energy body and the optimal energy distribution on the interconnected lines between any pair of energy bodies within Energy Internet. A distributed double-Newton descent (DDND) algorithm is proposed, which can asymptotically converge to the global optimal point. (10) In order to enhance the adaptability and flexibility of Energy Internet, the islanded and network-connected modes of multi-energy systems are modeled into a unified form as well as a distributed fashion. A double-mode energy management model is established to achieve the adaptive switching between islanded and network-connected modes. (11) We developed a coordinated inertial control scheme for wind turbine generator (WTG) and supercapacitor energy storage system (ESS) for temporary frequency supports. The system level small-signal stability analysis shows that the WTG ESS tends to improve the stability of the whole multi-energy power grid. (12) We developed a new optimization method for building microgrid energy management using reinforcement learning. The results and analysis indicate that the proposed algorithm is beneficial to deal with the problem of ?curse of dimensionality? for multi-agent microgrid HVAC system control and speed up learning of unknown power system conditions. (13) We researched how to manage real time power imbalance with Renewable Energy. The uncertainty of the PV power output is considered using chance constraints to guarantee the real-time delivery of its frequency regulation services. (14) We developed Optimal Scheduling of Battery Energy Storage System Performing Stacked Services. Grid-scale battery energy storage systems (BESSs) are at the forefront of technologies utilized to provide stability and flexibility to the power grid.

During the project, we collaborated with our local industry partners and National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, Colorado.

Findings from this research can be applied to technologies and demonstrations that shape the future of the electricity grid. The development of networked microgrids along with the proposed control, optimization and analysis methodologies will not only facilitate the increased penetration of distributed renewable energy resources but also enhance the reliable operation of low- or medium- voltage distribution networks.
Successful penetration of our technology into the energy market will have major societal and commercial impact and contribute in transforming our energy infrastructure to become resilient. Our microgrid control technology will help improve security, efficiency, and sustainability of our power and energy infrastructure.


Last Modified: 08/30/2022
Modified by: David Wenzhong Gao
